title: Visualising the output of Monte Carlo methods with ggsmc
text: use package algorithm output must tidy format, dimension parameter particle lies distinct row data frame. data sir_cwna_model provides example valid input plotting functions. data contains output particle filter (PF) applied target tracking problem. state x=(x1,x2)Tx=(x_1,x_2)^T tracked using PF two-dimensional, consisting (one-dimensional) position velocity target. value first particle first target distribution given (x1,x2)T=(3.0163,4.6682)T(x_1,x_2)^T=(3.0163,4.6682)^T. tidy format, stored two rows data frame, Dimension column gives index state ParameterName: e.g. row ParameterName=="x" Dimension==2, Value column gives value x2x_2. unfamiliar , way storing data many repeated values might seem wasteful. strength format can used consistently across different situations, allowing use general purpose packages processing , case, plotting data. data standard matrix format Monte Carlo output (.e. one parameter vector per row), can use matrix2tidy function included package convert required format algorithm output target distribution. function need supply algorithm output matrix format, name parameter represented output, integer index target output corresponds log_weights particle using SMC algorithm. using algorithm iterates multiple targets, matrix2tidy function called target, output call stacked together using rbind. sir_cwna_model data contains columns required use plotting functions package. columns required functions : Target, indexes target distribution, taking different integer values target. Particle, indexes particles, taking different integer value particle. ParameterName, uses string name parameter. Dimension, indexes dimension parameter, taking different integer value dimension. Value, stores numerical value particle, target, parameter dimension specified columns. output SMC algorithm, may additionally include LogWeight column store log (normalised) weight particle. column found data, particle assigned equal weight.

title: Visualising the output of Monte Carlo methods with ggsmc
text: plot_histogram plot_density functions may used plot, respectively, histogram density marginal distribution one dimension one parameter. LogWeight column present data weighted histogram/density used. functions, parameter (string) dimension (integer) argument need used. target variable set, function plot marginal histogram/density specified target, parameter dimension. target specified, points points specified parameter dimension used plot. plot_histogram function also takes bins argument, may used specify number bins histogram (argument specified, default value ggplot2 used). example, look 20th target sir_cwna_model data using histogram density.
code: plot_histogram(sir_cwna_model,                parameter = "x",                dimension = 1,                target = 20,                bins = 20) plot_density(sir_cwna_model,              parameter = "x",              dimension = 1,              target = 20)

title: Visualising the output of Monte Carlo methods with ggsmc
text: plot_scatter function can used creates scatter plot Monte Carlo representation joint distribution two parameters, two dimensions parameter. specify parameter dimension x-axis using arguments x_parameter x_dimension respectively. target variable plays role plot_histogram plot_density. LogWeight column present data, size points scatter plot used represent particle weights. illustrate plot 20th target sir_cwna_model data.  Note plot used two additional arguments, alpha max_size, adjust look plot. example importance points, found default value alpha = 0.1 (transparency points 0 1) low, default max_size = 1 (governing size points) small.
code: plot_scatter(sir_cwna_model,              x_parameter = "x",              x_dimension = 1,              y_parameter = "x",              y_dimension = 2,              target = 20,              alpha = 0.5,              max_size = 3)

title: Visualising the output of Monte Carlo methods with ggsmc
text: clearly understand output SMC ensemble-based algorithm can useful visualise evolution particles time. function plot_genealogy may used purpose, one dimension one parameter. use sir_cwna_model data illustrate function, showing evolution PF’s estimate target position time.  first arguments used plot_density function. used several additional arguments alter plot: use_initial_points (default TRUE) governs inclusion (otherwise) initial unweighted points drawn proposal used initialise algorithm. case chose omit points show estimate filtering distribution time. vertical (default TRUE) controls orientation figure. alpha_lines changes transparency (0, transparent, 1, solid) lines connecting corresponding points successive targets. choose omit lines making invisible. alpha_points changes transparency (0, transparent, 1, solid) points (whose size given LogWeights column included data. arrows (default TRUE) determines arrows included lines plot (omitted plot). illustrate alternative configuration genealogy plot, use output different algorithm: SMC sampler applied sequence targets parameter θ\theta begins Gaussian distribution, ends two-component mixture Gaussians.  SMC algorithm, due resampling step index ancestor particle ii target likely ii. produce plot lines connect particle ancestor, need additional column data named AncestorIndex.
code: plot_genealogy(sir_cwna_model,                parameter = "x",                dimension = 1,                use_initial_points = FALSE,                vertical = FALSE,                alpha_lines = 0,                alpha_points = 0.05,                arrows = FALSE) data(mixture_25_particles) plot_genealogy(mixture_25_particles,                parameter = "θ",                dimension = 1,                alpha_lines = 0.2,                alpha_points = 0.4)

title: Visualising the output of Monte Carlo methods with ggsmc
text: algorithms Monte Carlo point represents time series, index thus far represented column Dimension can thought indexing time. illustrate plot simulations stochastic Lotka-Volterra model produced run approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) algorithm. contained data lv_output.  plot weight (given LogWeight) time series represented width line. make lines visible choosing alpha = 0.5 compared default 0.1, change limits y-axis using ylimits=c(0,1000). one target, target argument need specified. max_line_width argument (used ) can used scale width lines plot.
code: data(lv_output) plot_time_series(lv_output,                  parameters = c("X","Y"),                  alpha = 0.5,                  ylimits=c(0,600))

title: Visualising the output of Monte Carlo methods with ggsmc
text: figures created using ggplot2, can modified using functions package. now demonstrate adding true target position onto plot sir_cwna_model data, changing style. also demonstrate ability automatically generate title figure.
code: data(cwna_data) plot_genealogy(sir_cwna_model,                parameter = "x",                dimension = 1,                use_initial_points = FALSE,                vertical = FALSE,                alpha_lines = 0,                alpha_points = 0.05,                arrows = FALSE,                default_title = TRUE) + ggplot2::geom_line(data=cwna_data,ggplot2::aes(x=Index,y=Position),colour="red",inherit.aes = FALSE) + ggplot2::theme_minimal() + ggplot2::theme(legend.position="none")

title: Visualising the output of Monte Carlo methods with ggsmc
text: histogram, density, scatter time series plots can animated, show output changes sequence target distributions. show code generating (looping) 10 second animations (set duration argument) showing sir_cwna_model data changes sequence 20 targets. time series, two possible animations. One, animate_time_series, shows time series particles evolve sequence (non-time ordered) targets. , animate_reveal_time_series, illustrated lv_output, animates time series show population particles evolves time.
code: animate_histogram(sir_cwna_model,                   parameter = "x",                   dimension = 1,                   bins = 20,                   duration = 10) animate_density(sir_cwna_model,                 parameter = "x",                 dimension = 1,                 duration = 10) animate_scatter(sir_cwna_model,                 x_parameter = "x",                 x_dimension = 1,                 y_parameter = "x",                 y_dimension = 2,                 alpha = 0.5,                 max_size = 3,                 duration = 10) data(`lv_output`) animate_reveal_time_series(lv_output,                            parameters = c("X","Y"),                            alpha = 0.5,                            ylimits=c(0,600),                            duration = 10)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Richard G Everitt. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Everitt RG (2025). ggsmc: Visualising Output Sequential Monte Carlo Ensemble-Based Methods. R package version 0.1.2.1, https://richardgeveritt.github.io/ggsmc/, https://github.com/richardgeveritt/ggsmc.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ggsmc: Visualising Output from Sequential Monte Carlo and Ensemble-Based Methods},   author = {Richard G Everitt},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.2.1, https://richardgeveritt.github.io/ggsmc/},   url = {https://github.com/richardgeveritt/ggsmc}, }

what: Visualising Output from Sequential Monte Carlo and Ensemble-Based Methods
title: Visualising Output from Sequential Monte Carlo and Ensemble-Based Methods
text: Functions plotting, animating, output importance samplers, sequential Monte Carlo samplers (SMC) ensemble-based methods. package can used plot animate histograms, densities, scatter plots time series, plot genealogy SMC ensemble-based algorithm. functions rely algorithm output supplied tidy format. function provided transform algorithm output matrix format (one Monte Carlo point per row) tidy format required plotting animating functions. package available CRAN can installed using: Examples use package can found vignette.
code: install.packages("ggsmc")

what: An animated density of a single variable across targets. — animate_density
title: An animated density of a single variable across targets. — animate_density
text: animated density single variable across targets.

title: An animated density of a single variable across targets. — animate_density
code: animate_density(   output,   parameter,   dimension = 1,   target = NULL,   external_target = NULL,   use_initial_points = TRUE,   use_weights = TRUE,   mcmc = FALSE,   xlimits = NULL,   ylimits = NULL,   default_title = FALSE,   duration = NULL,   animate_plot = TRUE,   save_filename = NULL,   save_path = NULL )

title: An animated density of a single variable across targets. — animate_density
text: output Output SMC EnK algorithm. parameter parameter wish view density. dimension (optional) dimension parameter wish view density. (default 1) target (optiona) specified, fix target, animate ExternalTarget (present output). external_target (optional) specified, fix external_target, animate Target. use_initial_points (optional) target specified argument TRUE, add initial unweighted proposed points output plotted. (default TRUE) use_weights (optional) FALSE, ignore particle weights density. TRUE, use particle weights. (defaults TRUE) mcmc (optional) TRUE, user indicating output MCMC algorithm. set use_initial_points=FALSE use_weights=FALSE matter user sets arguments . (default FALSE) xlimits (optional) Input form c(start,end), specifies ends x-axis. ylimits (optional) Input form c(start,end), specifies ends y-axis. default_title (optional) TRUE, provide default title figure. FALSE, title used. (defaults FALSE) duration (optional) duration animation. (defaults producing animation uses 10 frames per second) animate_plot (optional) TRUE, return animation. FALSE, returns gganim object can modified animating. (defaults FALSE) save_filename (optional) specified, animation saved gif filename. (default save) save_path (optional) specified along save_filename, save gif save_path/save_filename. (defaults working directory)

what: The output of an SMC sampler where the initial distribution is a Gaussian and the final target is a mixture of Gaussians. 25 particles were used, with an adaptive method to determine the sequence of targets, and a Metropolis-Hastings move to move the particles at each step. — mixture_25_particles
title: The output of an SMC sampler where the initial distribution is a Gaussian and the final target is a mixture of Gaussians. 25 particles were used, with an adaptive method to determine the sequence of targets, and a Metropolis-Hastings move to move the particles at each step. — mixture_25_particles
text: output SMC sampler initial distribution Gaussian final target mixture Gaussians. 25 particles used, adaptive method determine sequence targets, Metropolis-Hastings move move particles step.

title: The output of an SMC sampler where the initial distribution is a Gaussian and the final target is a mixture of Gaussians. 25 particles were used, with an adaptive method to determine the sequence of targets, and a Metropolis-Hastings move to move the particles at each step. — mixture_25_particles

text: Plot line graph showing parameter value vs dimension algorithm output.

title: Plot line graph showing parameter value vs dimension from algorithm output. — plot_time_series
code: plot_time_series(   output,   parameters,   target = NULL,   external_target = NULL,   use_initial_points = TRUE,   use_weights = TRUE,   mcmc = FALSE,   max_line_width = 1,   alpha = 0.1,   xlimits = NULL,   ylimits = NULL )

title: Plot line graph showing parameter value vs dimension from algorithm output. — plot_time_series
text: output Output SMC EnK algorithm. parameters parameters wish y-axis line graph. target (optional) target plot. (default use targets) external_target (optional) external target plot. (default use external targets, ignore column present) use_initial_points (optional) target specified argument TRUE, add initial unweighted proposed points output plotted. (default TRUE) use_weights (optional) FALSE, ignore particle weights line graph. TRUE, use particle weights. (defaults TRUE) mcmc (optional) TRUE, user indicating output MCMC algorithm. set use_initial_points=FALSE use_weights=FALSE matter user sets arguments . (default FALSE) max_line_width (optional) maximum size points plot. (default=1) alpha (optional) transparency lines plot. (default=0.1) xlimits (optional) Input form c(start,end), specifies ends x-axis. ylimits (optional) Input form c(start,end), specifies ends y-axis.

title: Plot line graph showing parameter value vs dimension from algorithm output. — plot_time_series
text: line graph ggplot figure.
